abstract.p: New study, reported in journal Nature, suggests amphibians known as caecilians, legless relatives of frogs and salamanders, use squishing, squeezing type of locomotion never before seen in vertebrate animals (S)

block.p: They look like gargantuan worms. They act like gargantuan worms. And a new study in the March 20 issue of the journal Nature suggests that they move like worms.
But they are actually slithering, tropical amphibians known as caecilians. And their squishing, squeezing type of locomotion has never before been seen in vertebrate animals.
They look like gargantuan worms. They act like gargantuan worms. And a new study in the March 20 issue of the journal Nature suggests that they move like worms.
But they are actually slithering, tropical amphibians known as caecilians. And their squishing, squeezing type of locomotion has never before been seen in vertebrate animals.

Biologists had long assumed that caecilians, legless relatives of frogs and salamanders, moved through their underground burrows like snakes. A snake plants one curve of its S-shaped body and pushes off from that anchor point, much as a human rock climber in a crevice would alternate pushing away from a rock wall with hands and feet.

But unlike snakes, whose bodies are relatively rigid, caecilians are ''just a big sack of fluid,'' said James O'Reilly, a graduate student at Northern Arizona University in Flagstaff. Mr. O'Reilly carried out the study with Dale Ritter and Dr. David Carrier, herpetologists at Brown University in Providence, R.I.

So caecilians employ a sort of water-balloon method of movement. Using the unusual, and hitherto unexplained, arrangement of muscles ringing its body, a caecilian squeezes itself tight, forcing its squishy, flexible body to elongate and propelling its head forward. Then the rest of the body follows.
Mr. O'Reilly compared the movement to that of an earthworm, an octopus tentacle or human tongue. ''Yeah,'' he said, ''they're really weird.''
